replies.msg:
Friends,
Today, the Hong Kong Leader Carrie Lam announced a formal withdrawal of the extradition bill amendment.
Some people believe this is a victory to the protesters. But I have to tell you that Hong Kong people have never literally “win” anything. We are still far from a relief.

In fact, a withdrawal of the bill amendment merely means the extradition bill is now “undone” to a level of what it has always been in the past 22 years. However, Hong Kong has already become a police state that is full of white terror in the past 80-ish days.

And in order to have Carrie Lam (HK government leader) to literally say “withdraw the bill,” we paid a very very heavy price.

We have two protestors (a teacher and a first aider) who lost their eye, more than six people committed suicide, over a thousand of people arrested... the youngest is just 13 years old. Many of the arrested are charged with riot crime. They could possibly face a sentence of 10-12 years.

Over the past two and a half months, the police force has been colluding with the triad gangs. Also, police officers are allowed to use all sort of unparalleled extreme violence, including weapons like pistol, expired tear gas, bean bag rounds, and rubber bullet to the protesters, journalists, and first aiders on site within a very short distance. This is already a total violation of safety protocol and human rights.

We also learned that some police officers tortured the arrested before an oral statement was taken. We have numerous cases of bone fractures, losing consciousness, sexual assaults reported during the period of suspect detention.

Under these circumstances, I believe the social movement is still far from an end. Instead, we afraid the gesture of “formally withdrawal” would serve as a delusion to the international community that the Hong Kong government has already fulfilled the protestors’ demand.

I hope to once again clearly state the four of the five demands here,

1. Establishment of an independent commission of inquiry into police conduct and use of force during the protests

2. Retraction of the "riot" characterisation

3. Release and exoneration of arrested protesters

4. Resignation of Carrie Lam and the implementation of universal suffrage for Legislative Council and Chief Executive elections

When Hong Kong people are still trying very very hard to fight for justice and freedom. I hope, I wish, and, if possible, I urge you to please stay with Hong Kong and support us in any way that you could think of. We need your help as we are now at a point of no return.
